column2: AMAZTIM Smart Watch, 60 Days Extra-Long Battery, 50M Waterproof, Rugged Military Bluetooth Call(Answer/Dial Calls) Fitness Tracker, 1.85" Ultra Large HD Display, AI Voice Assistant 24H Sleep Monitor
column14: Everything about the watch is right on. But there are two major problems. The software supporting the watche's reporting functions is, at best, inconsistent. The sleep function may be very good or non existent, even when worn the exact same way each night. The second problem is the claims about the battery. I have never been able to get more than 5 days from one charge, even though the company claims up to 60 days! Just ain't so. If they would straighten this all out, it would be an outstanding watch. As it is: unreliable, even worthless for anything other than keeping time.

column2: AMAZTIM Smart Watch, 60 Days Extra-Long Battery, 50M Waterproof, Rugged Military Bluetooth Call(Answer/Dial Calls) Fitness Tracker, 1.85" Ultra Large HD Display, AI Voice Assistant 24H Sleep Monitor
column14: I got this watch for two reasons. I already had a garmin vivosmart 4, which does super-well at SPO2 monitoring in your sleep (mail reason I got it) and remarkably well at activity tracking etc. It also had a very good android app interface for quickly viewing graphs of its running observations and more. Its flaws were a watch band that is too short and not adjustable, charge that only lasts for 4-5 days tops, and it ONLY does heart rate and SPO2 for health monitoring. So, I got the AMAZTIM, in order to get a much longer runtime per charge and its blood pressure monitoring as WELL as SPO2 and heart rate. It is also a much -- much! -- bigger watch than the vivosmart so I thought its interface might be a bit better and access to more advanced smartwatch features better as well. I was mightily disappointed. The ONLY part of its hype this watch lives up to is its run time per charge, which is easily more than a week, almost two weeks. What doesn't is: a) Watch faces that look like they were designed and intended for teen-age adolescents who like cartoon animals. Seriously? Not one, single, watch face that actually uses the vast real estate of this large watch for something other than cartoons, fancy backgrounds, science-fiction spreads? Nothing that (for example) displays time/date/heart rate/SPO2/steps/BP? There's plenty of room for all of this...but instead we get cartoon beaches with only the time. b) The Blood Pressure it measures is completely useless. I mean, off by 20-30 points useless, when compared to BP taken by actual cuffs by actual nurses or physicians. 20-30 points low useless -- I'm healthy as a horse according to the watch, 106/66. Only not -- PROBABLY more like 126/80 -- if not higher (which is the problem). c) Heart rate is not too accurate either. I tend to run slow, but it thinks that I'm up at 82 after sitting completely still for over an hour. d) SPO2 almost always reads 99%. I do have an oximeter to compare to, and it reads more like 96-96% where the Garmin reads 94-95%. I trust the Garmin to be consistently low, because if I e.g. hold my breath to drop SPO2, it remains a couple of percent under. I'm not sure I trust the always 99% reading. Again, great if true, but almost too good. But the worst of all is the Da Fit app. It isn't even in the same UNIVERSE as the Garmin Connect app. Garmin plots data on an actual graph with time as an actual axis. You can see how your heart rate changes over the entire day, as it constantly samples it. It doesn't CONSTANTLY sample SPO2 -- I wish -- but it DOES sample it for a selected four hour window while you sleep, making it actually amazingly useful for determining whether or not you have Sleep Apnea when your wife (the physican) thinks EVERYBODY my age has it -- but the Garmin says that I do not. Just sayin', worth it right there. Cheaper and easier and I'll bet just as effective as a sleep study, and it runs EVERY NIGHT (one reason the Garmin runs out of charge in five days). The AMAZFIT only samples SPO2 when you, by hand, tell it two -- scroll four screens, press a button, wait. It doesn't automatically sample at night or regularly in some window. It only samples heart rate when you tell it to -- well, it actually does sample it all of the time but doesn't send the data back to the app and display it as a function of TIME. BP is shown only "for the last seven times", but it doesn't actually LABEL them with the TIME or DATE you took them. Ditto SPO2 -- last seven times you hand measured it, without any sort of timestamp, in a BAR CHART not even a graph. Look, almost anybody's smart watch will track steps, stairs, hikes, etc -- fitness training is easy if rarely completely accurate as they rely on things like accelerometer reading a lot more than they rely on sampling your GPS coordinates. The key health metrics they can currently reach are heart rate (a very few more than just "rate"!), SPO2 (enormously useful if it will run overnight), and blood pressure. Except that so far, BP just doesn't seem to work, and EEG-quality heart results are still only on very expensive watches, and NONE of these are worth much if you can't SEE HOW THEY VERY WITH STRESS AND TIME ON A REAL GRAPH. I suppose it is back to the drawing board. It's very difficult to get a clear and unbiased review of what is out there. I'm tempted by an EEG-capable watch, but that is super limited right now. I'd love accurate -- note accurate, within say 5 torr -- BP, SPO2 (within 2%, consistently one war or the other around oximeter readings), heart rate -- all displayed in real graphs with time axes of a reasonably small granularity -- once a minute, say, or once every fifteen seconds depending on what one is looking at. WITH week plus runtime per charge. And sure, with activity/sports stuff too, but that's a dime a dozen and easy.

column2: AMAZTIM Smart Watch, 60 Days Extra-Long Battery, 50M Waterproof, Rugged Military Bluetooth Call(Answer/Dial Calls) Fitness Tracker, 1.85" Ultra Large HD Display, AI Voice Assistant 24H Sleep Monitor
column14: I (almost) never write product reviews....mostly because there are so many others that do, and my reviews would tend to be redundant. However, I did want to comment on this watch. I have been using an Apple watch for six or more years. It is a Series2....that's how old it is. I keep thinking it is going to die any day. Because of that, over the last year or two, I have purchased two other smart watches, as well as a fitbit....thinking that at some point in time I am going to need to replace my Apple watch. This watch by far exceeded my expectations. It seems to be made well, the app works great, it has a plethora of watch faces to choose from (note that the faces can't be modified to include "complications", like an Apple Watch can), and the battery life is exceptional. No more charging every day. I can't attest to the accuracy of some of the activity measures, e.g. steps, calories burned, miles walked, sleep stats, etc. but they seem to be pretty close. Close enough for me anyway. It syncs up with my iPhone with no problem. I get notices of calls, emails, texts, and even from my ring doorbell. Because I've only owned this watch for 3 weeks or so, I can't comment on its longevity. But for the price, I consider this a great value, and a very suitable alternative to an Apple Watch.

column2: AMAZTIM Smart Watch, 60 Days Extra-Long Battery, 50M Waterproof, Rugged Military Bluetooth Call(Answer/Dial Calls) Fitness Tracker, 1.85" Ultra Large HD Display, AI Voice Assistant 24H Sleep Monitor
column14: I've been looking for the perfect "smart watch" for about a year now, and I've sampled four different brands, two watches within one of those brands. This one makes the grade, and it's the one I'll be using for the foreseeable future. Apparently the name of the watch and model is "Tank M2" although as with other imports, if there is a real brand name, it's a mystery. The box just says "Smart Watch." I found "Tank M2" on the enclosed User Manual. Some of what I am about to say is based on other comments I've read here, and I will lead with the most important one for me. I actually purchased this watch because of the claim of long battery life, and so far it is living up to that promise. After 3 days of pretty hard use, the battery is still at 87%, which suggests it will last the two weeks promised. One reason my experience may be better than others is that I don't use Bluetooth, don't see any reason to use the watch as my phone, and also disabled the feature that turns the watch on if one raises their arm. I know from my experience with other watches that that feature burns a lot of battery, and I don't mind pressing the button when I want to see the time. Several people have commented on the available dial faces and I have to say that I agree that the overwhelming majority of these dials seem to be childish and useless. But all that matters in my opinion is that there are a few dials that serve the purpose, and as you can see in the photo, I'm perfectly happy with this one. Now for the nitty-gritty on features: the sleep tracker is superb, best one I've found. I can't comment on Blood Oxygen because I have no way to know whether that's accurate, I guess I hope it is because it's giving me a good result. Several people have complained about the Blood Pressure measurement, here I have to strongly disagree and say that this is the best watch for measuring BP I have found. I have a medical cuff, so I can compare results. Of course they are not identical--for that matter, I get different results on my cuff from the one my physician uses. The watch is within 10 points of the cuff on both systolic and diastolic. But that's all missing the point. No one should be relying on these sorts of devices for Blood Pressure other than one important thing: if the watch reports that you are having high or low BP, that's an indication you should get a check up. That's what matters. Of course these watches were designed to count steps, and the step counter on this watch seems to be extremely accurate. There's very little lag time between starting to walk and the watch starting to count those steps. This brings me to the one issue I have had, and the reason I'm withholding one star from my review. For some reason, the watch uses a standard of 4000 steps to a mile. Not only is this wrong according to my other four watches, it's wrong by a course I've mapped out using my car's odometer. According to all four watches, a mile for me is between 2300 and 2500 steps, and according to the one-mile marked course, I need 2325 steps for that mile. I have contacted the company's technical service department, but so far all they've done is offer me an extra watch strap for my inconvenience. I'm happy to accept the strap, but I'd also like to have a more accurate distance measure. Wags like to recite "your mileage may vary", but here the problem seems to be that the mileage isn't varying--it's stuck on 4000! The watch does seem to be built like a tank, I have no worries about its durability and water safety. For now at least, this is the watch I'll be wearing every day, and compared with the other four watches I have tried, I'm willing to say it is also the best "bang for the buck."
column16: The Best of the Last Four Watches I have Tried

column2: AMAZTIM Smart Watch, 60 Days Extra-Long Battery, 50M Waterproof, Rugged Military Bluetooth Call(Answer/Dial Calls) Fitness Tracker, 1.85" Ultra Large HD Display, AI Voice Assistant 24H Sleep Monitor
column14: Watch arrived when promised. Looks good quality construction, heavy duty, rugged. I didn't buy it for it's good looks! A bit larger than I'd anticipated, would not work on small or delicate wrists. Nice long silicone strap with plenty of holes for the buckle. I've had it a week, it has good & bad qualities. Pros: *Nice little levers on the strap to assist in attaching it to the watch, also looks like a standard strap would fit *AWESOME battery life, still at 74% after a week *Nice clear watch face, can program shake to display & program how long it stays on *Once you get the hang of it, easy to scroll through the various screens * once set up, easy to continuously have heart rate displayed (the main reason I got the watch) *brightness of display can be adjusted. Still can't see it in direct sunlight, but angled away from the sun on a bright day it's still visible Cons: Only 2 analog watch faces available, neither of which is the one shown on the Amazon page. I've Emailed Amaztim about this, still waiting for a reply *Notifications are an almost inaudible buzz, no vibration *Cannot get the BP & SpO2 readings to work, they just show zero. Not an issue for me, blood oxygen unimportant, & blood pressure with anything other than a sphygmometer are notoriously inaccurate *Pedometer function reads about 80% more than actual # of steps & distance. 50 paces registers 86, a measured mile shows 1.87. But it's consistent, whether I do it with hands in pockets or swinging my arms as I walk, so, knowing the error, it's still a useful measurement *Smaller issues, battery life only displays on the app, shake to display inconsistent, sometimes illuminates with the smallest of arm movements, other times needs a good shake to wake it up. So, in conclusion, in spite of some shortcomings, it's still a good watch, well worth the price. Update: I've found extra watch face options, including the one showing in the ad! You can change watch faces directly on the phone itself, but also in the app, which has more options.

column2: AMAZTIM Smart Watch, 60 Days Extra-Long Battery, 50M Waterproof, Rugged Military Bluetooth Call(Answer/Dial Calls) Fitness Tracker, 1.85" Ultra Large HD Display, AI Voice Assistant 24H Sleep Monitor
AMAZTIM Smart Watch, 60 Days Extra-Long Battery, 50M Waterproof, Rugged Military Bluetooth Call(Answer/Dial Calls) Fitness Tracker, 1.85" Ultra Large HD Display, AI Voice Assistant 24H Sleep Monitor
column14: I purchased a AMAZTIM 5ATM for my husband primarily to help him keep track of his blood pressure and after researching several smartwatches I decided to go with the AMAZTIM 5ATM. The trouble is I am whatever the opposite of a tech person is and my husband is about as techie as you can be. While he very much appreciated the thought, he immediately knew that neither this smartwatch, nor any other smartwatch, was at all accurate when it came to blood pressure. But he strapped it on and like any other tech person started through all of the options and functions. Naturally, it told the time so we can skip that. What I got from him was the heart rate and O2 were very much in line with a store-bought pulse-oximeter and therefore, as far as he was concerned, reliable and useful. There were a few things that bothered him but I am much more of a positive person so letâ€™s start with the good points. I already mention pulse rate and O2. That seems first rate. Battery life is excellent. Three days and itâ€™s still at 80%. The charger cable, while not the usual mini-USB, connects magnetically. Iâ€™m guessing thatâ€™s to avoid a slot that water can get into. Itâ€™s a nice feature. The watch paired with his iPhone very easily. On the downs-side blood pressure reading were very off but he knew that even if I didnâ€™t and I donâ€™t count it against the product. My husband gets text messages and other app notifications frequently and since he keeps his phone on silent mode and in his pocket, he sometimes misses them. Getting those notifications from the watch sounded like a good deal and he set everything up on the watch and companion phone app, DA Fit, I think it is. He got very frustrated because hardly any notifications from any app came through to the watch. Not zero notifications which would mean it didnâ€™t work at all, but some, which for a very impatient person like himself frustrated him more since he tried to figure it out. He did not figure it out. The weather function, while he didnâ€™t really care about, said it wasnâ€™t paired, which he didnâ€™t know what that meant (the teeny instruction booklet wasnâ€™t helpful), but it did work... once. Again, Mr Frustration cared more about why it worked once than not at all. My husband is an avid cyclist (heâ€™s on his bike more than heâ€™s home sometimes). The Sport Mode, which was supposed to be a long press on the second button, never worked at all. Three categories that really didnâ€™t work is problematic. I did contact the seller and got a prompt next day reply from, Iâ€™m assuming, a different time zone. They offered to remediate the issue but unbeknownst to me he sent it back - sigh. I would have given them a chance. Men, right? Bottom line: donâ€™t get any smartwatch for blood pressure and this product in particular has definite shortcomings. The watch itself gets 3 stars but I added a star for the seller who tried to make it right even if my husband didnâ€™t wait.
column16: Basic decent smartwatch but don't expect accurate BP readings

The physical activity tracking works very well. The only negative possibly about the watch is you canâ€™t send texts or make telephone calls through it as you can with some much more expensive similar products. Now to fix a problem I have ran into probably four times since Iâ€™ve owned the watch this is screen, freeze wear the watch face will not respond to your finger swipes. This can be fixed by repeatedly, pushing the power and then the back buttons repeatedly in fast succession for probably 150 reps. Eventually, the screen will turn off and restart and the watch will work properly at this point. It has been a good watch. I would recommend it, and I would buy another.

column2: AMAZTIM Smart Watch, 60 Days Extra-Long Battery, 50M Waterproof, Rugged Military Bluetooth Call(Answer/Dial Calls) Fitness Tracker, 1.85" Ultra Large HD Display, AI Voice Assistant 24H Sleep Monitor
column14: Original review is below. I had to downgrade my review because one of the two watches keeps shifting to a loading display and locks up there. We have to reboot the watch to get it functioning again, but the problem just comes back after a couple of days. I have attempted to contact the vendor, and have left messages on their website, but they just don't respond. I can no longer recommend this product if they cannot back it with even rudimentary support. ---------- Overall, I like this watch. Every other tracker watch I have owned has been junked for the same reason: the proprietary band broke, and would cost almost half the price of a new watch to replace. Not so with this watch. It has a standard watch band, so you can replace it with just about any standard watch band at a normal band price. The screen is easy to see, and the controls work well. I have had no complaints with the function, use, or asthenics. The battery life is great. I can wear the watch for a week, and only dip down to 40% remaining. The only issue I have with the watch is with data syncing to the app, especially sleep data. There is no method of initiating a sync manually. When I wake in the morning, the watch shows my overall sleep hours, but the app is at 0 for the day. Hours later, is will still say 0, even though other data is updated. My sleep data will not show up in the app until sometime in the evening. On a couple of occasions, I was not able to view my sleep breakdown until the following morning. The blood pressure is also not very accurate, and sometimes wildly inaccurate. But that is more an issue with the tech available. No watch I have used (including the high end expensive brands) has been accurate for blood pressure. The pressure cuff is the only reliable measurement available. So nothing against the watch here, just don't rely on the BP readings if that is an important measurement for you.
column16: Overall good watch, but has some issues

column2: AMAZTIM Smart Watch, 60 Days Extra-Long Battery, 50M Waterproof, Rugged Military Bluetooth Call(Answer/Dial Calls) Fitness Tracker, 1.85" Ultra Large HD Display, AI Voice Assistant 24H Sleep Monitor
column14: I was very impressed with the watch when I first received it. For once, I had found a smartwatch that fairly accurately recorded my vitals - Pulse, blood oxygen, blood pressure, and steps. The watch has more than a sufficient number of watch faces to choose from and it is a perfect size for my wrist. The battery life, I feel, is not as good as they claim, but it does last for about 8-9 days after a full charge. Of course, I only use a limited number of notifications, do not use my watch for a phone, and only use the functions that make sense for me as a 71-year-old male. The application that you are supposed to use with the watch is not as good. It does not stay connected to the watch and takes an excessively long period of time to connect and show your data after opening the app. I have an iPhone 14 so that should not be an issue. Another thing is the weather. The application only connects to the local weather when you press the weather data in the upper left-hand corner of the app, and it rarely transfers that information to the watch. I like to be able to look at my watch to see what the current temperature is. Now for the reason that I am only giving this watch a one-star rating and I will update it if the manufacturer responds favorably - or unfavorably. Virtually all of the functions of the watch, and especially the ones that I use most often, quit working 4 days after the 30-day return date expired. I now have to deal with the manufacturer. It still gives me the time and date, notifies me of emails that I receive from my phone, and gives me my blood pressure reading. Nothing else. It is not easy to get to someone that you can actually speak to at Amazon when you press the "Call Me" button on the "Get Product Support" tab. When I finally was able to speak with someone to ask for the manufacturer's phone number, all she had in her system was their physical address. She was very polite, hard to understand, but polite, and gave me the warranty department's email address and instructed me to request the information from them. I have done so, and now am waiting for a response. I have purchased a metal watchband and screen protectors specifically for this watch, so I hope the manufacturer will honor their 2-year warranty and make this right. At this point, I would not recommend spending $99 for this smartwatch, but will update this review once my problem is resolved - hopefully satisfactorily. UPDATE: After several emails to AMAZON, I finally was given good contact information for the seller and I made contact. That same day, Thursday, February 8th, I received a message from the seller telling me they were going to send me a new watch and told me that it was not necessary to return the malfunctioning smartwatch. The scheduled delivery date for the replacement smartwatch was Thursday, February 15th. The seller exceeded my expectations and the new watch was delivered today, Monday, February 12th! Everything seems to be working as it should and the BP readings that I am getting are actually realistic! AMAZTIM honors their warranty, so for that reason I am bumping my review up to 4 stars. If AMAZON's communication methods were a little more customer friendly the rating would be 5 stars. Thank you AMAZTIM. If the replacement smartwatch continues working as it is now, you will see no more on this review.

column14: I primarily purchased this smart watch for its ruggedness and it has held up phenomenally. I've owned this smart watch for about 3 months now and I've used worn it in the pool, hot tub, and sauna and never had a problem. Battery life (which is great, lasts weeks at a time for me) has not degraded due to high heat from the sauna. Cons: As for the features, I was disappointed that I wasn't able to receive notices for messages from Teams or Facebook Messenger. As far as size and comfort, it is rather large and sticks out farther from the wrist than I'd prefer but I can't really complain too much on that front since my primary reason for purchasing the smart watch was for it's ruggedness and rugged/thin just don't go together. On Accuracy, the step count is wildly off (too high). Days I notice a large spike in steps seems to coincide with days I was driving, so I'm pretty sure it picks up vibrations while driving and thinks your walking the entire time...just a guess. Overall, if you're looking for a ruggedly built phone that can withstand high heat, swimming, and just plain getting knocked around a lot, this smart watch may be a good fit for you.

column2: AMAZTIM Smart Watch, 60 Days Extra-Long Battery, 50M Waterproof, Rugged Military Bluetooth Call(Answer/Dial Calls) Fitness Tracker, 1.85" Ultra Large HD Display, AI Voice Assistant 24H Sleep Monitor
column14: I purchased this watch to replace a Lotus watch purchased in late February of 2022. That watch stopped syncing with the app after clock change for DST in November. Since then watch cannot be set and their support just seems to be doing run around including requests for information from a blocked email address. Anyway, I purchased this M2Tank watch to replace the Lotus. It cost half the price and is so much better. The Tank M2 was delivered on December 26 and has needed charging the first day and only once since then (today is Jan 6) with a charge of61% remaining today. The sleep tracker is great showing deep, light, and REM sleep periods. The choices available for customization are plentiful. The breathing and exercise tracking options make this a very valuable instrument. The extra provided tempered glass watch face cover is a added bonus. Overall, I highly recommend this to anyone. The price cannot be beat and this watch out performs my wife's phone specific watch.

column14: After leaving my 1st updated review I was promptly contacted by the customer service and they offered a full replacement for the watch. I accepted and relayed that I would amend my review based on their making the situation right. I do like the watch and what it offers. I am glad a replacement is in the works. ** Old Post** Ok so here we are some 45 days later. The watch was fickle and unreliable. It constantly disconnected and would not restart when rebooted. The only way it would restart was to leave it on the charger for a few hours. Finally it stopped reading steps, BP, oxygen nada. Contacted the vendor because I was 15 days past the return window and the gave me a Gmail address to contact. So the take home point...if you have a 100 dollars to waste this is your ticket. **Original** Out of the box I found this watch to be accurate and beefy as heck. Easy to set up and good battery life so far. Nice selection of faces but that is not really that important to me. Overall a great value for the price. The only negative is that the alarm is not silent. Will update after I put it through it's paces.

I've also used it to work out and measure my heart rate, and these have been accurate based on what I typically see for an average gym session. column14: This smart watch is good at this price point. Although itâ€™s a little bigger than other smart watches I have owned, it has a lot of features I havenâ€™t seen before. One of the biggest features is that the GPS is pretty accurate and syncs to towers quickly. This is an important feat for those who rely on GPS for workouts. In addition, the steps counter is pretty accurate as well (I find that itâ€™s hard for any smart watch to be 100% accurate). It was quick and easy to set up with the app and syncs with the app quickly. Here are other features I found impressive: - A ton exercise options and sports recognition - Accurate and consistent weather - Ability to a sync contacts and answer phone calls - Displays text and phone notifications - Accurate heart rate and blood oxygen level - Flashlight - Music - The ability to connect your phoneâ€™s camera to the watch and command the watch to take the picture (handy if you have your phone propped somewhere to take a group photo) - Find my phone - Touchscreen - Large clock face I noticed that the watch still receives notifications when my iPhone is on do not disturb mode. For some people this isnâ€™t an issue, but itâ€™s worth noting. Overall, this smart watch has a lot of features at a great price point.

column2: AMAZTIM Smart Watch, 60 Days Extra-Long Battery, 50M Waterproof, Rugged Military Bluetooth Call(Answer/Dial Calls) Fitness Tracker, 1.85" Ultra Large HD Display, AI Voice Assistant 24H Sleep Monitor
column14: I really appreciate this watch and the features it has. First off, the smart watch was very easy to pair to my phone. I have an Android phone, and it only took a few minutes to pair the watch with my phone. First enable Bluetooth and find the device listed as C20 Next, download the app that's shown in the QR code. Once you have the watch paired via Bluetooth to your smart phone and the app is downloaded, your watch ready to go, and should be syncing to your smart phone. The connection has been great thus far; it hasn't disconnected/lost connection to my phone. As someone who has suffers from pulmonary lung disease, I was very excited when I found out this smart watch has the capability to track my oxygen saturation, heart rate, and blood pressure. In addition, you don't have to do anything, the watch will automatically to measurements periodically throughout the day. It's helping me monitor and compare results over a few days. I suggest authorizing Google Fit so your hearth history is accessible when it. For me, it helps to have a history when I meet with my pulmonologist. The watch has great standby battery life, and it's light weight. After m three days it's only dipped minimally in available battery percentage. I highly recommend this! **Updated** So it's been several days now since I first posted the review and I am amazed how little the battery has drained. Needless to say this smartwatch has fantastic standby battery life; especially considering it's constantly looking for/measuring heart rate. As you can see from the photos the readings are very accurate. I own a pulse oximeter and a blood pressure monitor to keep my pulmonary hypertension in check. My resting heart rate is 95 bpm, which may seem high, but the reading is accurate and normal which makes this product more the reassuring.
column16: Easy to set up, very accurate, keeps me updated with many aspect of my health

column2: AMAZTIM Smart Watch, 60 Days Extra-Long Battery, 50M Waterproof, Rugged Military Bluetooth Call(Answer/Dial Calls) Fitness Tracker, 1.85" Ultra Large HD Display, AI Voice Assistant 24H Sleep Monitor
column14: Watch looks great, was easy to pair with my phone. The ap is pretty simple but you have to be cool with giving it permissions as it demands access to EVERYTHING to function as anything but a step and sleep tracker. It tracks steps almost perfectly, but it is way, way off on distance. Ei I walked 4.5 miles in 97 minutes this AM. It got my steps right at 9256. Unfortunately, it says I only went 2.33 miles. No biggie since Google Maps tracks it as does Google Fitness, but it's silly that I had to give it access to literally everything on my phone except my Bank info (and it did ask for it, demanding it to use the ap which I had to manually block) and it can't track how far someone walks/bikes/rides/hikes etc. Phone calls are fine, alerts are fine, text are fine. The waterproof part is also 100% legit as I have soaked this thing numerous times and don't bother taking it off when I shower half of the time. Good product for the money.

column2: AMAZTIM Smart Watch, 60 Days Extra-Long Battery, 50M Waterproof, Rugged Military Bluetooth Call(Answer/Dial Calls) Fitness Tracker, 1.85" Ultra Large HD Display, AI Voice Assistant 24H Sleep Monitor
column14: âœ… Goes in the pool âœ… Goes in the hot tub âœ… Goes in the shower âœ… Goes in the ocean âœ… Goes in the sand âœ… Gets sprayed with sunscreen âœ… Gets sprayed with bug repellent Still works with no problem! I own an Apple watch also which ran me literally 6 times as much as this watch, and I think since I am a light smartwatch user I would be fine with just this one. It pairs for phone notifications, does heart rate and exercise tracking, and has alarms and timers. The best part has to be the battery life though. I recently spent a week at the beach, and rather than take my Apple watch and have to worry about it and charge it every night, I took this watch. I fully charged it before we left, left the charger at home, and when we got back it was still at 54%. It will literally hold charge for weeks. The UI is very, very responsive. Swiping around is nice and quick. I tested the heart rate monitor with one of those O2 sensor things you put on your finger and it was accurate. Now nothing is 100% perfect so here are some things I noticed. * Setup and some operations *requires* a phone. You cannot even set the time without a phone. This is a SMARTWATCH. If you're not going to at least pair it once with a phone this is not the watch for you. After the initial setup it functions independently, with only a couple of things like changing alarm times and getting the weather not working. * The features cannot be rearranged. Out of everything provided, I use the music controls the most to repeat and switch songs on my phone. This feature is the *last* one in the list, so if I ever leave it I have to swipe alllllll the way back. * The font used for notifications appears to not support emojis. If anyone sends you a smilely you're going to get a "?", then have to go to your phone to see it. All in all, it's an amazing product with a lot of value for the money. The watch firmware is upgradable, so if they fix any of the above issues, which I think is likely, it will be even better.
column16: Rugged, responsive smartwatch with amazing battery and features for the cost.

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: Update: one day after writing the below review, I adjusted the time to catch back those 8 seconds. 30 minutes later the crown was gone. Just decided it had somewhere else to be, I guess. Will attempt to return/replace. I had really high hopes for this, but now I'm just sad. Very sturdy watch. I'm impressed with the classic utilitarian style. I've worn this daily for about a week. The watch face is rotated about 1/2 second off the second hand, but it doesn't seem to interfere with the visibility in the date window. The movement was set off time.gov and has dropped about 1s per day. Out the box, the nylon strap was very stiff and uncomfortable on the edges. I soaked in warm water with fabric softener overnight, then manually twisted, stretched, and bent. It still isn't supple, but is much more comfortable. For the price, I think this is a fantastic watch. I work with my hands and I think it will stand up to some pretty serious abuse that I'd be too scared to subject an expensive watch to.

column14: PLEASE READ IF YOU'RE CONSIDERING BUYING THIS WATCH! I really wish I could give this watch 5 stars -- it's quite good looking, feels very solid, and the price was right. My last Times Expedition lasted ten years until I lost it. Unfortunately, this particular watch doesn't keep time, which is the only reason to buy a watch, after all. I have had it for 3 months. About a week after I received it, it lost 8 minutes. I figured I had loosened the crown by mistake, so I re-set the time, and moved on. The it started losing a couple of minutes here, a couple of minutes there, so I had to re-set it every few days. Then about a month after I got it, the watch lost 55 minutes, which caused me to be late for an event and ruined an entire evening for me and my wife. Now a day doesn't go by when it doesn't lose at least 2-3 minutes. Honestly, this watch is absolutely useless, and now it is too late to return it. PLEASE - do yourself a favor and check out all of the similar one star reviews for this watch before you consider purchasing one!!!

Due to that misunderstanding, I bought a second, different Timex watch. So after another month or so, my 3rd Expedition Scout watch arrives in the mail, which I didn't need, because I no longer needed another watch. OK, whatever, now I've got two watches. Good thing, I guess, because several months later the back spontaneously fell off my Expedition Scout. I'd replace it, but at this point the value of the time I've spent dealing with Timex Customer Service is considerably greater than the amount of money I spent on the watch.

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: Nice watch for the price but my crown vanished after just a few weeks. This is touted as an "outdoor" watch for active folks but I disagree. Speaking to others on forums the crown seems to be a bit too large and being that it is exposed it is vulnerable to being ripped off. So if you want a nice looking watch with simplicity in mind for casual wear this is the watch for you. If you plan on being active, especially activities that could compromise the crown move on to something else like the Expedition Camper that has protection for the crown. I really liked this watch, hence the 3 stars (hell the things still works, I just can't adjust the time) but seeing as I am not the only one who had a crown just disappear stay away if you plan on being rough with it. 2020 UPDATE: Going to bring this down in stars, my second watch has had it's crown broken off again. The exposed factor coupled with the shaft that goes into the watch being thin and weak this watch is not for the active. The second time it broke on me was while I was putting my hand into a cooler to grab a 6 pack of beer and the adjacent beer ripped the crown right off.
column16: Nice watch, terrible crown design. Not for active folks.

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: First thing first: I ordered the watch with a black wristband and received it with a grey wristband. The last couple of items I had received from Amazon had to be returned or exchanged, so I thought I could learn to live with the grey rather than go through the hassle. Not to mention, I don't like being that guy who constantly returns stuff and/or complains. I am now wondering if I made a mistake. The date function only works sporadically. Most days I have to advance the date. Then there is the time keeping. It seems to have a problem keeping time accurately consistently. Both of these problems have left me wondering what happened to Timex quality. I have been a loyal Timex customer for almost all of my adult life. The watches have been of superior quality to any other in their price range. That is important to me as someone who cannot afford to buy a watch that costs $250 or more, nor do I see the point of spending that kind of money on a watch. Nevertheless, the time slipping has been minor enough that I have hung onto the watch and continue to wear it. It still looks good.

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: Cliff Notes Version: A nice watch, but you cannot replace the battery when it dies. I purchased this watch eight months ago, and I really liked it - until the battery went dead. Of course I expected to replace the battery eventually, although I did expect it to last more than just eight months. The problem is not that the battery needed to be replaced, the problem was with the difficulty of replacing it. The rear cover is very difficult to pry off the the watch to replace the battery. However, that's almost trivial compared to getting the rear cover back on the watch after replacing the battery. I have fairly strong hands, but I could not squeeze the back cover hard enough to get it to pop back on to the case no matter how hard I tried. I Googled for a solution, and the only thing I found was a YouTube video that shows using a C-clamp to press it back on while using a piece of cardboard to protect the crystal, so I followed those instructions. I kept tightening the clamp to squeeze the back cover onto the case, and it never did pop in the way it is supposed to. However, I did bend the rear cover so badly that it pushed against the works and damaged the mechanics of the watch. Now it will not run correctly. It doesn't really matter, because I still cannot get the watch put back together so that I can wear it anyway. So, if you can afford purchase this watch, throw it away when the battery dies, and then purchase a new watch, go ahead and buy it. However, do not expect to just replace the battery when it reaches end of life.

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: I bought this in November of 2015 to replace my Seiko Model SNK809 Sport 5 automatic. I had been wearing the Seiko since December of 2011, and I really beat the hell out of that watch. I actually prefer automatics over quartz movements, but I figured Timex has been around forever... The Timex Expedition watch is absolutely massive compared to the Seiko, and I am not a fan of this trend of super big watches. I did like the indiglo feature that became a major selling point for the brand in the 90s. Like others have mentioned, the crown is the weakest link in the watch. The quartz movement is clunky but keeps excellent time; however, the crown is so large that it has often been captured and pulled out during normal wear. This causes the hacking feature of the watch to stop the movement, and correct time is lost at that point. This has happened to me on multiple occasions, and I work 75% of the time in an office. This is unacceptable. A smaller or lug protected crown would prevent this from happening. I replaced the strap immediately with a NATO strap, so no problems there. The case has become pitted and discolored a little over time, and I attribute that to sweat (I sweat quite a lot and it takes a toll on all of my watches). It actually looks like a cross between rust and salt water corrosion. The indiglo feature stopped working after about a year of daily wear. I replaced the battery, but that did not fix the problem. There was obviously a malfunction inside the watch itself. The glass was the best part of the watch, and it held up quite well for the past 2.5 years. The crystal on my old Seiko seemed to get a scratch if I breathed on it hard. The Timex has started to show a few small scratches on the crystal in the past 6 months. Overall, for a $35 dollar watch you can't expect a Rolex, but I believe there are great watches out there that meet a price point. If the indiglo had not crapped out I would have given it three stars. Maybe I should give it 3 stars anyway given that it still keeps accurate time as long as that huge unprotected crown doesn't accidentally get pulled. As soon as my new strap comes in, I will be switching to the Casio MDV Marlin dive watch. It's on the large side for my taste, but it has a screw down crown.
column16: Not the $35 Rolex I was looking for

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: I loved this watch when I started using it. And function well and it looked and felt great when I was wearing it. The indiglo feature was great as I am a frequent backpacker and I could easily read the time in the middle of the night without disturbing any tent mates. After three months, however, the indiglo failed to work. The button would not depress. At six months, it became difficult to set the time. The connection between the time setting knob and the watch movement began to slip periodically. Sometimes it would grab and sometimes it would just spin. Then at nine months, the setting knob came off. I was able to screw it back in, but it no longer worked. The action is stuck showing the wrong time. During the first three months, I thought I had a watch to last my lifetime. Unfortunately it did not even make it to our one year anniversary.

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: I don't usually buy watches that are under $100 so I knew I was taking a risk with this one. It's a nice watch, HOWEVER the back came off completely the second month I had it. Too late to return but way too soon for a watch to fall apart of any price.

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: I spend every work day in wilderness areas collecting fisheries research data and needed a tough watch that didn't cost too much, but was also stylish enough to wear it daily. I use watches to keep track of time for data purposes. I thought I had found it in the Timex Expedition Scout. Loved the styling, easy to read, comfortable, tough(ish), and had the features I needed. I found two design flaws, however, while subjecting this watch to abuse during my daily activities over the month and a half that it survived. 1st, the crown popped into its adjustment position on multiple occasions which paused the watches time keeping and left me thinking it was earlier in the day than it actually was - this could be fixed with a screw-in crown. 2nd, the bar that the strap wraps around to attach to the watch is a compromised strength point - it broke when the watch got caught on a branch. I don't understand why the case wouldn't be a single piece, including the strap-attachment points, to increase durability. The mounting bars are very skinny and obviously weak even in appearance (silver bar pictured). The rest of the watch is very tough and held up perfectly, including frequently submerges in water. This is the watch I want to wear, and I'm struggling finding a better option on Amazon, just very disappointed in these two flaws.
column16: Loved It Until Failure at Weak Points

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: ** Timex Expedition Scout - Indiglo (cream dial). + It's a Timex & low cost. There area lot of Timex out there. + Fast shipping/receiving. Watch in typical Timex package. (Small instruction print as expected.) + Indiglo feature. + Wears well on my wrist. Fairly easy read in adequate lighting. - date is hard to read. + Band is soft and comfortable. I prefer NATO Bond but this is comfortable out of the box. Clasp & keeper seems Timex typical. + Crown easy to position inward/outward, decent grip so easy turning to adjust time/date. + Good fit/finish for a watch at this price point. - Looses 6+ minutes per 24 hours. I reset it (and hacked to the second) and again next day lost 6+ minutes and I stored it in a different position this time. Maybe later I'll swap in a fresh battery and if that don't work, in the trash it goes. - Second hand while holding the watch upright facing me the second hand from 7 to 1 is close on the markers (close). After 1 it falls between the marks about half way in between them until its back to the 7 mark. Seems 1/2 second slop or backlash. > Yes I saw the good and bad reviews but decided I wanted to take a chance on this make/model. Loosing 6+ minutes per 24 hours is disappointing to me. I grew up with a few Timex watches and since I have a few Seiko, Orient, Casio, I wanted to add a few Timex's to my current herd just for the sake of having a Timex on the wrist now & then. Just a simplistic basic cream dial Timex ticker. Guess I wasn't lucky this time - I'll look for something else. I know there are Timex watches that hold time well, I just didn't get it this time.

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: Over the years, I had gotten used to not wearing a watch, but I needed a watch to wear during my BSA Wood Badge course. So I started shopping for suitable watch here on Amazon. I purchased this watch largely based on other reviews and my own past experience with Timex as a brand. I needed an easy to read watch that could handle rain yet be cheap enough that I wouldn't worry about possibly losing on a camping trip. This watch seemed to fit the bill - it was waterproof, had a simple easy to read face design and Indiglo, plus it was a Timex, what's not to like? I wore this watch out on a normal Scout outing with my troop and everything was great. I really liked the watch, it was easy to read, kept excellent time and looked good. We didn't do a lot of hiking that weekend, but I wore it every day and was very pleased with it. It had no problem surviving a light rain on this trip. I wore this watch out on the first of my two Wood Badge weekends (this past weekend as I write this review), it worked fine until my third day. I looked at my wrist to see the time stopped at 7:12AM, which didn't seem right to me. My fellow patrol member had 9:16am. I was going to re-set my watch when I realized that there was no longer a crown knob. Apparently it fell out during one of my hikes that morning and it appeared the watch would not function without it. I had to go the majority of my third day of Wood Badge without a watch, thankfully it at least lasted through my days as Patrol Leader and Assistant Patrol Leader. This watch was never subjected to any major stress. It was never dropped, bumped or scraped - just some light hiking and occasional 'high-spirited' motions. When looking at the reviews for the watch before buying, I had seen a few reviews talking about the crown falling out, but assumed it was just a handful of isolated incidents. There were lots of positive reviews, and I considered Timex a good brand. I am now in the process of returning this watch for a refund. The experience has soured me a little on Timex, a brand I used to equate with relatively inexpensive but quality timepieces. I understand that this was not the most expensive watch, but I am disappointed that pieces could just fall off like that.

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: This is a revision from 4 stars to 2 stars after using it for several months. It's a good watch, but two problems have arisen since I reviewed it earlier. 1. The watch band seemed durable, but it is so stiff that it is hard to latch, and in doing so the band gets bent in a way that will certainly cause early failure. 2. Both hands (minute hand and hour hand) are just about the same width, so when the time is 1:05 or 4:21, in the dark it is hard to tell the time. The two visible hands are the second hand and another hand, but takes a moment to realize it's not the minute hand and the hour hand--a I don't usually "study" my watch for the time, but I glance at it. It's okay at 10:10 when the hands are separate, but when they overlap, it is very hard to read. These seem to be design flaws--not in the watch's mechanics, but in its interface with people. My earlier Expedition did not have these problems. Earlier review: The Expedition came ready to use; I set the time and it began ticking. Bold face, but very busy with all the writing and the hours from 13-24, so it is kind of hard to read at a quick glance. Watch band seems durable and the watch back is stainless steel. The date is a bit tiny for my aged eyes, but that's what glasses are for. This is a replacement for the Timex Expedition that I had for over twenty years--or rather for 5 watch bands. No care needed or given, except to replace the battery every couple years and to advance the date every 30-day month.

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: Bought this as a replacement for a dying Casio G-Shock. Wanted something inexpensive that would still fit my needs. Originally, I thought this watch was the one. I loved the design and the colors matched my uniform pretty well. Unfortunately, there's an issue with my unit that made the built-in light feature trigger randomly on its own, so eventually the battery started dying on me as the light would be on for who knows how long before I'd catch it. Subsequently, my time started to drag and fall behind as the battery started dying on me. I couldn't stick with this one and I wasn't interested in dealing with the warranty process, so I replaced it with a Citizen Eco-Drive. Many times the cost of this watch, yes, but I got to the point where I'd pay for something that worked 100% than deal with issues. Overall, I'd say grab this one if you're willing to go down that warranty/customer service road should it come to it.

The crown is halfway worn from rubbing against the top of my hand. Iâ€™ve been wearing Expedition watches since high school and this is around number 12. I didnâ€™t think it would be water resistant anymore so replaced it(with the one in the picture). When the new one needs replacing, Iâ€™m sure itâ€™ll be with a Timex Expedition. Update: Didnâ€™t last 90 days and the light went out. Replaced the battery, didnâ€™t help. I guess Timex watches arenâ€™t what they used to be. Iâ€™ve always wanted a Luminox. Time to upgrade

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: What is up with Timex? This is the second time I have ordered one of their watches and a different version arrives. The Expedition Scout on Amazon shows a grey case with a khaki watch face and is described as such. Instead, the watch sent had a black case and light grey face. Even the band was different...dark grey, not dark brown. Stupid, unforced error. Change the friggin product photo if you change the product!!!! This isn't a rocket science expectation, especially if you keep the product number the same. Get in the program Timex!!... I should also mention that Amazon packed my watch with another item in a box way too big for them both with no packing material, so both were swimming around in the box. The small Timex box showed signs of damage from internal knocking around and the plastic watch stand inside was snapped in two...didn't give me much confidence that such force didn't also affect the watch...

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: I really like the look of this field watch. But it hasn't even lasted me a year. I found three major issues: (1) the indiglo backlight stopped working after only four months of use; (2) the genuine leather band has retainer loops for excess band that are certainly not genuine leather, and which started falling apart during the first month of use; (3) the last issue is by far the most significant. Although it will keep time perfectly for weeks at a time, it will suddenly lose 10-20 minutes, causing me endless headaches and resulting in me arriving late for appointments. I even replaced the battery recently in case a low battery was causing it to lose time, but within a few days it was off again. Don't buy this watch if you want a reliable watch that keeps time.

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: I really like the readability of the display, the rechargeable illumination on the hands and the overall look of the watch. Iâ€™m bummed that the backlight stopped functioning after a little over a month. Iâ€™ve reached out to timex CS, will update when it is resolved.
column16: Great Watch, Backlight Died Very Quickly

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: This watch was everything I was looking for in a watch, simple analog face with a backlight and a nylon wrist strap. I wore this watch doing heavy work outdoors and I thought it was holding up well until about 8 months in the backlight stopped working. About a month ago I somehow lost the strap than holds the band in place, and a few days later the leather strap attached to the wrist strap snapped so now the wrist band can't be secured at all. The watch itself still works but with the strap loops broken and missing and the backlight not working this watch has become a paperweight. If the straps hadn't broken I probably would still be wearing it, but now I am looking for a new watch.

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: Bought this one to replace exact model that stem broke almost immediately. I liked the overall size and design and just assumed I'd snagged the stem as I never knew where it went, so I ordered a new one. Original box was somewhat 'worn' looking upon delivery, but there was no damage inside the box that I could find. This one started losing time almost immediately (15 mins a day) and then was ok for a few days, then started losing time, etc. The first event I went to that i needed the 'indiglo' (lighted face), I found that it didn't work. Not good, as the event was a 24 hour outdoor event and I needed the lighted face. It was too late to return at that point (and I hate returning items). I decided to try a new battery and the indiglo now works. I thought it was a relatively new model watch, so can't believe it was held in inventory but so long. I'm going to assume the watch model overall is ok and I just got two lemons. But having to replace a battery within a few weeks of purchase was disappointing.
column16: Battery had to be replaced almost immediately

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: I thought this would make for a decent beater watch, but it drives me nuts and I canâ€™t wear it for multiple reasons. First off, it tick so loudly it sounds like thereâ€™s little gnomes inside building a railroad. Second, I donâ€™t like nato straps so I put the watch on a two piece strap but the lugs curve so far down past the bottom of the watch that they dig into my skin which really hurts after a while. Itâ€™s not an issue if you leave it on the nato but I find them to be uncomfortable. Third, the color way that I picked isnâ€™t great, mainly because I canâ€™t see the green seconds hand even in good light. It just blends in with the dark grey dial. So anyways those are my main gripes. I do own a few Timex from their reissued line like the Milano XL and I really like them but this one is a hard pass for me.

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: The watch keeps good time. The Indiglo feature stopped working not long after I got it. Timex fixed it under warranty, for $8. I got it back, and a couple months later, it broke again. But it's out of warranty now. This watch is good if you just want a way to keep track of time, but don't count on the Indiglo feature.
column16: Keeps good time, but Indiglo is unreliable

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: The strap loop nearest the housing started to shred in six months and broke in one year. The strap started to show stress marks after about a year. At two years, the remaining strap loop is split, slides up and down the band and lets the strap free. Less than 3 years, and I need to buy an aftermarket warchband. Very odd for leather. The date window needs to be at least 50% larger to read the date behind it because it casts a shadow on the numbers, making them too hard to read. And it's not illuminated by the night light. You need to mess around and mess around trying to get the stem in just the right position to change the date at the end of every month. The detent is just not recognizable by touch and feel. It's faster to wind the second hand around and around, hour by hour, for 24, 48 or 72 hours as needed. The minute and hour hands are iridescent, but the seconds hand needs a larger arrowhead and a dab of fluorescent. The paint job on the bezel seems to be thin because there are several places where bare metal is showing through. It seems to keep good time. The push button light works fine and is real handy. Overall, however, I cannot recommend this model.

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: Nice watch for the price. Just be careful when working, I caught it on a shelf and one of the spring bars broke free. Donâ€™t recommend using during hard labor.

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: It has been a very long time since I wore an analog watch, so it is taking some time to get used to it. I have also found that my old eyes cannot read the smallest numbers on the dial, so I need to make an appointment with my opthalmologist.

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap

This morning, though, I was washing the strap after getting some dirt on it and accidentally dropped the watch proper from countertop height. Watch landed at an angle on its face and the glass exploded. Thankfully, it exploded inwards, so I didn't have to clean up any shards, but the watch itself no longer works. If you're looking for a general-purpose watch, this should be fine for you, but if you have a more rugged use case, as I apparently do, you may want to keep searching.

column14: I like this watch, it looks nice and is functional -- glow in dark and back lit functions are very good. But the winding knob is fragile and breaks off (picture). When the first one broke off, I lived with it. Even though I couldn't change the date or activate glow-in-dark. When we switched from Daylight Savings time two weeks ago (and couldn't change the time) I figured it was time to buy a new one. Today, while just putting my jacket on, the knob on the new two-week old watch came off. It must have been pulled off, since the watch stopped. I can push it back in to start the watch, but since I can't change the time I'm pretty much out of luck. If Timex can make this part more strong, I would give it 5 stars.

column14: First of all, let me preface this by saying that I understand that this is an inexpensive watch. However, I've had better luck going to Walmart. Guess I should've done that, but someone gave me an Amazon gift card. This watch is not nearly as readable as the pictures suggest. At first I thought there must be some protective plastic cover on the face, but no. The numerals and hands are not a bright white. They're beige at best. Second, I liked the cool-looking strap, but the stitching is cheap and scratches my wrist. Third, as others have noted, the set knob feels like it will break off at any time. Fourth, I cannot exchange this watch. For some inexplicable reason, DeShaun told me that I could only return it, wait for a refund, and then buy another watch. Really? It's 2022, folks. Finally, the act of actually reaching a live rep took several efforts. I realize we're still living in a covid economy, but if Amazon can't properly staff its ranks and refuses to pay an attractive/ liveable wage, perhaps it ought to shut down for a while.

The crown can be pulled out very easily. It is getting pulled out when I am wearing it and then it gets pushed back in without me noticing it.

column14: If you want a wind-up or self-winding wrist watch, this is not what you are looking for, even though it will come up in your search. Otherwise, it's a good watch.

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: I like this watch but it's heavy. By that I mean it's hard to keep upright on your wrist. The light and face are nice, but it sneaks around your wrist. My biggest gripe is how loud the ticking is. I tend to sleep with arms above my head and you can clearly hear the tick...tick...tick. I have to remove the watch before bed which counteracts the reason I wanted a watch to check the time at night. It's a great workday watch but I don't wear it at home.
column16: It's a simple, attractive watch. But loud.

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: After receiving one replacement watch already, I give up. Both watches had misaligned second hands! The stock photograph of the watch on Amazon with the second hand landing between the increments is "accurate". Both of my watches are just as inaccurate. It may seem picky, but one of the things I like about this watch is that the second hand snaps into place with each second - unfortunately it misses the mark each time. Otherwise, I love the watch and would have given it 5 stars. The Indiglo feature is great. The face is easy to read. I like that it is a simple design; not fussy. The face background is off-white - kind of light ivory, which gives it a classy look. The case is very dark grey - nearly black. So, it should also work well with a black band, which I will eventually put on it. The leather band is very nice. Stiff as new, but will surely soften over time. With a little more QC at assembly, this would be a 5 star watch.

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: When you look up Timex watches you will see a few reviews stating their low quality and how they malfunction in various ways. God's honest truth, this is the second Timex I bought via Amazon and it broke as well. This time the wheel used to adjust the time or date sheared off. The first Timex was solar powered and the battery would not keep its charge...even after leaving it under a lamp for hours. They are loud, they are made in the Philippines or China, and they break...a lot. Get something else or be prepared for the eventual breakdown. The tough thing is finding a minimalist watch, with hands, that is durable, and does not have all the useless junk (chronometers, fake diver spinning wheel, etc...).
column16: Broke in Less Than a Year, Like My Other Timez

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: I bought one of these watches about a year and a half ago and I loved it. Itâ€™s nothing special but itâ€™s a great watch. Recently I have tried ordering another one so I have them to switch off, or like as a backup if the battery goes or something, but every time I order one it arrives damaged. The first time it was that the indiglo didnâ€™t work. The second time the crown was totally missing. And both times the boxes were crushed but the actual packaging slip was fine so I know it wasnâ€™t the driver who did it. Hopefully they can fix whatever is happening in their supply chain. Or maybe Amazon purchased a damaged pallet of them at a discount and is trying to sell them like this. I would still recommend this watch but be prepared to return if it arrives damaged.

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: The watch itself is nice for a timex but the band is poor. Gave it to my son for Christmas and the band is already coming apart.

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: Bought this watch on 01 Aug 22, by 01 Sept 22 I had to replace the Watch Band Pins, on 10 Oct 22 I dropped it and it stopped working. Yeah, I'm pretty rough on watches. It's a nice watch, lights up well at night, keeps time well, the band is tough, but the watch is not tough enough for me.
column16: Timex Does Not take a licking and does not keep on ticking

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: I liked the premise of automatic watches: use the movements of your wrist to charge the watch. I figure I'd start with something inexpensive (and I've preferred Timex watches for years). Unfortunately, automatic watches (and anything other than quartz battery watches) aren't the best at actually keeping time; I found that I had to adjust the time in this one almost once a week in order for it to stay accurate. Also, if you don't wear it, the watch stops and you have to start all over again (or you have to purchase a watch winder). This particular watch stopped cold after a few months of use and I've not been able to get it to restart. This watch is just a bit smaller than a lot of quartz watches you're probably used to. The watch case and strap are of good quality. After this little jaunt with automatic watches, I've decided I'm completely content with a traditional quartz battery watch. Automatic watches are not for me.
column16: First foray into automatic watches; they're not for me

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: Overall I like this watch. I wear it everyday and it takes a beating. The glass has a few scratches and the housing is scuffed. But it holds up. Itâ€™s light and comfortable. The back light works well. The big issue is that over the course of a week my watch slows by 4 minutes. Itâ€™s about every day and a half that I notice I am a minute behind. Also, this ticks extremely loud. If youâ€™re easily annoyed and prefer quiet, probably donâ€™t buy this watch. If you need a rugged watch and you donâ€™t mind keeping up on the time every couple of days then buy it. Itâ€™s a cheap watch so I wasnâ€™t exactly expecting perfection.

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: I had high expectation for this watch. I went thru two of them. The first one died after a few weeks, the battery I'm assuming. Being just a few weeks old I returned it for another. The second one lasted about a month and the time/date adjustment knob fell out and was lost. I am a fireman and I wear my turnout gear daily. This gear has cuffs that wrap around my wrist and thumb. I constantly had issues with the date and time being changed due to the cuffs moving the adjustment knob. My gear is more than likely the reason the adjustment knob broke on the second watch. Other Timex watches have features that will prevent this from happening and I'm going to try them next. I never had issues with the watch adjusting from long sleeve clothing. The watch in my opinion is the perfect size (diameter) and the band took a few days to break in and was comfortable after. In a quiet atmosphere the ticking is noticeable, it didn't bother me much. Also, I didn't shower with this watch because the band would soak up water and take a few hours to dry. All in all I would keep this watch if my work clothing would not be able to adjust the time and the date.

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: Really liked the watch for the money until the crown snagged on an Ethernet cable and popped right off. Exchanged for a timex standard. The movement was a little loud but not so bad as some reviews make it seem. The leather band looked a lot nicer after getting a little leather conditioner.
column16: Crown popped off in a week

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: I've owned many of these Expedition watches, which I love for their low cost, accuracy, and Indiglo luminance. This is the best looking one yet, and the yellow second hand makes timing things in dim light much easier. The downfall is that the buckle is defective. The tang or pin is too short to catch the body of the buckle securely, and when it slips through the buckle, the watch can fall off. Sure, I can replace the strap, but I shouldn't need to. The tang is also much smaller in diameter than on my previous Expedition, whereas beefier is better for a field watch.

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: The watch looks nice, get a NATO strap and it looks like a proper. Sadly a lot of stuff did break. The indiglo doesn't work anymore cuz the stem you have to push in doesn't work anymore. I think this is a real major failure point, as I had a weekender which had the same problem. If you put too much pressure like from bending your hand to push it, it might snap. I can still adjust time when I pull it out though. I also dropped it a few times, and had about a month where it would lose about 15mins over 30 mins. Watch repairers told me it's not worth a fix, so I dropped it again, and it seems to have fixed the problem. Also yes, it is very loud, I could hear it from 5 feet away in a quiet room, but you stop noticing it after a while. Best thing about this is the looks, but if it finally craps out I'm gonna look at the Bertucci's.

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: Pros: Pretty good for the price, stylish, orange second hand is a nice touch Cons: Very standard timepiece, nothing special, can get an automatic for a little bit more Timex watches are exactly what you expect. They're nothing amazing, but they're not bad either. You're getting a reliable timepiece from an American company (although Dutch owned and Asian made now). This particular style looks like a field watch and is good for everyday casual wear. There's not too much to say about it - it has very classic dimensions and design. The strap that it comes with is pretty cheap, although that's expected for a sub-$50 watch. However, it can easily be replaced with NATO straps for a unique look. If you're looking for a cheap everyday watch, I would actually suggest you look into a Seiko 5. There are tons of different designs available and if you want something that looks like this, the SNK809 is pretty close, albeit a bit smaller. The field/military style Seiko 5s are around $50 on Amazon, so yes, you have to spend a little bit more, but you're getting a lot more in return. The 7S26 is a great automatic movement and is going to be much better than this quartz movement. Modern Timex watches aren't anything like the original American-made ones, so if you really wanted an American watch, you wouldn't be getting one with this one anyway. Give the Seiko 5 a look and compare the two; I guarantee you won't be disappointed with it.
column16: Not much for a Timex watch, about what you'd expect

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: I got this watch when I was working in lawn care because I needed a sturdy time piece that would stand up to my abuse(from an active outdoorsy teenager). It has held up decently, but after about 3 months of constantly being worn night and day, outside in the heat and covered in sweat, it started to develop pitting of the metal on the case and on the knob. It was not too bad at first but has now turned into almost a full ring of corrosion on the innermost underside ridge. Then, about two weeks ago, after about 1 months of constantly being worn (shower and occasional swim included) the indigo illumination stopped working, which was one of my favorite parts of this watch. The illumination failure is the main reason of me writing this review. Other than these two downfalls, pitting and illumination failure, I have liked the watch and had no other complaints. I really like the styling and the band that came on it.

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: Paint chips off the clasp and the band frayed pretty quickly. After three months of use I don't really think it is presentable except in camping environment, where it doesn't matter. However, Pros were that the face lights up nicely, keeps very accurate time and the arms register with the numbers well. I found it to be very comfortable to wear (smallish wrists) and medium rugged. The watch band it turns out is my main complaint and also that sometimes I would find that I had fired the light while sleeping, so was not sure how long it was going to be until I get a battery. I think this is a good gift for a kid who is gaining to play paintball or airsoft or an office worker. One last critic note is that the day of month hand is impossible to see. I have relegated it to "wear if I might damage a better watch" pile. Maybe a new nato band with heavier duty material could resurrect it. My other watch is a Casio Pathfinder Tough Solar ABC watch and that thing is indestructible...I wanted this one for wearing out to dinner or just something a little lighter, but I don't trust it anymore. Though for others, I think all these issues mentioned might be solved by adding a beefier nato strap.

column14: I've had a few analog Timex watches over the years with no issues. This one is nice, however the indiglo stopped working after just a couple weeks. My two other cheap Timex watches are over 10 years old and still work fine. Edit. Looked up how to fix the indiglo. On the stem , there's supposed to be a tiny e-clip that presses against the indiglo switch when you push the crown. This clip must have come dislodged somehow, because when I opened the back of the watch it wasn't there. The e-clip is tiny, so it could be anywhere. I got another e-clip out of an old timex and put it in this watch with some tweezers and now the indigo works again.

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: I liked this watch right up until the crown broke off. It was rather light weight and sat nicely on my admittedly small 6-3/4 (17.1cm) wrist. The band was a bit on the long side for my wrist but the excess was easily tucked back into the NATO style strap. I have always been a fan of the indiglo feature on Timex watches and this one was as good as any of them. While a 50 meter water resistance is good enough for most usage, I've always questioned why Timex rarely makes watches with higher water resistance. 100 meter water resistance may be overkill for most daily usage but I've personally felt that overkill is often under rated. Now to the crown. This watch has a rather large crown that sits out in the open with no case bosses to shield it. I personally wear watches on the inside of my wrist and whether or not that was a contributing factor to the crown breaking or not I can't say for certain, but the size and lack of protection for the crown would seem to make it more susceptible to damage and breaking. I will admit that I did not bother to send it in for repair as there are no assurances that it would be covered under warranty until they receive the watch. If my interpretation of the warranty statement is correct, the warranty only covers the movement but does not detail whether or not the crown would be considered part of the movement. It also very easily have been declined as abuse rather than normal wear. A non-warranty repair would have cost about as much as a new watch after shipping, so I bought a different watch instead if having this one repaired.

It is also loud when off your wrist (e.g. at night) and needs to be placed in a cushioned drawer to absorb the sound.
