I took it apart to dry it out, but had to have a jewler put it back together (there's a special press to do it). Eventually the water resistance problem became too much and it quit working. I discussed this with my jeweler guy, and he said that the best watches are the same way. That while they say water resistance, unless its a dive watch, you're going to run into the same thing. He suggested taking it off everytime it would get wet. I'm not going to do that. So i'm going to keep buying cheap watches ever year or two or three, and keep running through them. Works for me.

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: Overall it's a very decent watch and I am satisfied with it, considering the price (I bought it on sale for around $45). I'm a little surprised that even my wife has mentioned a couple of times that it's a nice looking watch. Don't get me wrong, no one will mistake it for a $300 watch but I like how it looks and that's good enough for me. I wanted an inexpensive daily watch with Arabic numerals, easy to read and not too cluttered, with a little bit of field watch look and this watch met the need. For comparison's sake, the other option I was considering was a Seiko 5 field type watch, which would be fine but also at least 3 times more expensive and I didn't want another Japanese watch, I already have a Citizen Promaster so I'm good on that score and I didn't feel like coughing up a few hundred bucks for a Swiss automatic movement. I'll list my pros and cons and make it short: Pros: - good looking face, large Arabic numerals - size is about right for my personal taste, I don't like larger diameter watches but some people do - light weight was moderately important to me - accuracy, telling the time accurately is a watch's reason for being, and I think this is plenty accurate, about the same my Citizen Promaster or even a little tighter, really, but I'm not such an important person as to worry about a couple of seconds off here and there - solar, so no battery changes to fool around with the Expedition Solar version I purchased Cons: I don't have any strong negative opinions for this watch, particularly considering the price bracket we are in, but I will say - the lume is a little on the weak side, it doesn't last very long in my opinion so it would be hard to read at night or in a dark environment - height, I could wish it were a little thinner, it's not terrible but I just feel it sits a little taller than it has a right to To sum it up again, it's very decent watch and I would give it 4 and 1/2 stars

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: Ordered this watch as my first watch since I was a kid, wanted something that looked good but wasn't flashy. Overall the watch is great, comfortable, looks good, and does its job of telling time. My only reason for not giving this watch a 5 star review is because when I went to order the watch it was labeled as a prime item, while it was in my cart for around 30-40 minutes while I was doing other shopping it magically left prime status and was being shipped via 3rd party. I didn't think much of it because it was still free shipping, however it was now 4-7 days shipping. No more than an hour after I placed the order the watch went back to prime status. Seems a little fishy to me but anyways I received the watch just as the description stated but in an odd way. The watch came in a Timex box (that wasn't taped shut), however inside the Timex box was a joke. The watch was on the plastic "wrist" ring but the ring was not connected to the base used to showcase a watch, it was tossed in awkwardly. The watch was already ticking, not sure how long it has been running for but I probably should replace the battery to be safe. With that the labeling on the base was in French none of the labeling was in English, the directions and information documentation were all in French. Luckily there were no scratches or signs of wear on the watch otherwise I would have returned it because it looked repackaged. Outside of the packaging issues the watch is great, easy to set the time/date. The nylon band stretches slightly as you break it in. I was between two holes where the wider one was just a little too loose and the tighter hole was just a little snug. I toughed it out on the tighter hole for a few days and it slowly stretched slightly and fits wonderfully now. I have noticed when setting the hands the minute hand tends to click into its slot just slightly slow of where it should be. It tends to lag a little behind the minute marks as it moves. Even when attempting to set it properly. It hasn't run slow at all for the week I have had it or shown any issues of being off. The ticking is noticeable if you are in a dead quite room, place your ear right next to it or if you leave it on your night stand and sleep in dead silence like a heathen. I sleep with a low fan on and cant hear it at all, I had to turn off everything and put it next to my ear to hear it tick. Unless you live in absolute silence or have super hearing you most likely wont notice the ticking. Update on this watch (12/5/16) The crown is completely unprotected so it will catch on things. Mine caught on my pants and snapped off completely with the stem still inside. This happened within the first 2 months of owning the watch. I had to send it to Timex repair to have it repaired. They repaired it and had it sent back in about 3 weeks time. The repair was covered free of charge but they billed me for shipping the watch back to me, after I paid to ship it to them. I think this is a little upsetting for a watch that didn't last more than 60 days before it broke. Shipping in total cost me half what the watch did in the first place. I will just buy a different watch next time. I have read a few more reviews after buying the watch that state the crown snapped off or fell out on many of these watches.

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Black Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: I haven't had a Timex watch since before my 14th birthday, when my parents got me a beautiful Seiko self-winding watch. I still have that watch (53 years later...) and still love it. But its oh-so-stylish charcoal grey face with stainless hands isn't readable in the dark. And since my bedroom doesn't have a nighstand clock, I like to have a readable watch for when I wake up and wonder what time it is. So for my most recent birthday (I've now reached the age where I avoid saying my last birthday, in case it proves prophetic), I bought this Timex. I like watches with white dials, and this one has large black numerals for 1 - 12 (around much smaller numerals for 13-24), and chunky hands with lots of luminous paint in the middle. It seemed like a good solution... ...and then I touched the stem and got the Indi-Glo experience. It's lovely, a blue-green disc against which the hands stand out very boldly. Though if I've recently been in any kind of light, the Indi-Glo *almost* isn't necessary: the luminous paint in the middle of the hands is fairly bright for a long time after exposure to light. Still, for its intended purpose, I'm loving it: press on the watch stem in pitch darkness and the time is clearly visible. Negatives? The leather on the watchband is a nice color but not too luxurious. To be expected for the price, and I can always get a band I like better. But it fits well, it's flexible, and the color (a sort of cappuccino leather with a brushed finish) is subtle but pleasant. I haven't yet tested its water resistance, but hey, forty million John Cameron Swayze commercials can't be wrong, yes? And I can't speak to its durability, because I've only had it for about a week. But it's a good watch for everyday wear -- or every night, in my case.

column14: My last Timex large faced watch had died - mostly, if I am honest, due to needing a new battery that no one in my town could replace since our only jewelry store had closed some years before. I had been saving for an Apple watch that I wanted mostly because of the latest health features. In reality I was not keen on having a watch that included more â€œconnectivityâ€ and was also not keen at having a timepiece that needed â€˜chargingâ€™ either. So after some more thought I decided that an Apple watch was not really something I needed to spend money on and that another Timex would be a better choice for me. I wanted a light colored, large, face with a silver bezelâ€¦and a date would be nice to have. So many faces were dark, but then I landed on this light faced Expedition choice. The black bezel is not really an issue and I am very happy with my choice to buy another Timex watch that is modestly priced, and durable. I like slip through bands so that I can buy watchbands that coordinateâ€¦.especially pleased with a plaid Timex replacement band found here on Amazon. Buying another Timex large faced watch was a great choice for me!

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Cream Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: I am a tinkerer, and my wife knows I love watches. I told her that I loved them when we met 24 years ago, and when in doubt about gifts, she defaults to a watch. I have Rolexes, Movados, Patek Philippe, a Breitling, an Omega, and (the last gift, for my 60th birthday), a Chopard. She also bought me a Seiko a few years ago. The reason for the background isn't to brag on my watch collection... In fact, when I told her I liked watches, I meant that I like to wear them, but a Seiko or Timex is more my speed. So, I wore the Seiko when doing yard work, rebuilding engines, tinkering under the hood of my antique cars. My son was helping me one day in the garage and he said, Dad, why are you wearing a $2500 watch while banging around under the hood of your truck? I almost fell over. My last Seiko was about $100... I had no idea it was anywhere near that expensive! So, I immediately went on Amazon and bought this little jewel. I wear it routinely when tinkering. I also wear it to work in an office setting, while swimming, and I even went scuba diving with it instead of my trusty Rolex Submariner (my first gift from my wife). The Timex is rated to 50 meters, and we went down to about 35 meters (120 ft) and it was just fine. I could read it easily at that depth as well and it didn't get any condensation or water inside the case. The watchband is made of a canvas like material, and I was able to rinse off the saltwater after the dive. GIven the abuse I have heaped on the watch, I can assure you it will not let you down whether wearing it to work, banging around on an antique truck, or even exploring a reef off of St Maarten!

column14: The style of this watch face (font, spacing, configuration) is incredibly simple and it is easy to parse at a quick glance. I've typically worn digital watches for this reason and avoided watch faces where I need to spend any more than a second to know what time it is. The only complaints that I have so far are that the watch band is not very comfortable and the light easily triggers when the back of my left hand is pushed back towards it. The light isn't a huge deal, but I will likely change out the watch band. I've worn this watch in the shower and the pool and haven't seen any problems with water resistance either. In addition, I've worn this watch everywhere and do not see a single scratch on the glass which I'm very happy about compared to many plastic/plexiglass windows I've had on watches such as my previous digital Casio. Overall, I'm happy with the watch and the simplicity of the piece and the fact that it has held up really well in all conditions!

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Cream Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: This is my second Expedition watch. I bought it simply because it came in denim blue to go with the jeans I wear nearly every day. The dial is big and readable, the hands stand out, and the crown is big and easy to grasp for accurate setting. So far, it is keeping time very accurately. Timex's Phillipines-made brass-case watches are simple and dependable. I have seen some with chronograph-style buttons; I can't vouch for all the extra bells and whistles. But the simple time-only or time-and-date watches are a good value.

column14: The slogan for the Timex, back in the sixties was: Takes a lick'n and keeps on tick'n. I accidentally left this one in my pants and put them through a 20 minute wash agitation cycle in my machine. When I saw it on the bottom of the tub, I thought for certain it was dead. Not so. It worked perfectly and the band, once dried out, was like new. The whole watch is like new! Takes a lick'n and keeps on tick'n.

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Cream Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: I bought this directly from Amazon about 2.5 month ago for just under $30. I bought the version w/the green canvas strap shortly before all three versions of this Expedition Scout watch were lumped together under one sales page and the original reviews for each version were deleted. The green strap version was the lowest rated and seemed to have the most problems. Possibly a coincidence or possibly the different versions were made slightly differently or at different factories. The most common complaints associated with all the versions were the crown and stem coming loose and falling out or the watches ceasing to function in a matter of a couple to several months (possibly they were older stock and the batteries did not have much life left). I took a risk on the lowest rated one because I like its style the most and wanted a contrasting sweep second hand. My overall essential criteria in choosing a watch was water resistance suitable at least for swimming, analog face, quiet, accuracte, a sweep second hand (to be able to quickly time brief events on the cuff and set exactly to the second with the atomic clock), easily visible hour and minute marks, and a dial that could be read easily in pitch dark throughout the night. The last was the hardest criteria to meet. I was not able to find a single watch with luminous hands that I could easily and reliably tell the time with throughout the night, despite claims to the contrary. Even hitting them with bright light for a good while before hand wouldn't get them through the night. In terms of the luminous markings this one is no better. But its back light feature more than makes up for it. As far as I know Timex is the only one to make an analog watch with a backlight. Press the crown and in the dark the entire face is clearly visible with a nice cool glow that doesn't interfere with my night vision. This is one watch that fully met all my criteria. Great easy to read face. Can set precisely to the second with the atomic clock. Accuracy is a loss of 8 seconds per 30 day month over the last 2 months. Every time I reset the day of the month I reset the time to the second with the atomic clock. The water resistance has held up through numerous showers and high tub submersions. The watch is also pretty quiet. It's not totally silent, but to hear it tick I have to hold it close to my ear. The canvas band could be better but is easily changed if desired. I have kept it so far. It was a bit stiff, rough and irritating when I first wore it. I 'fixed' the stiffness to a large degree by flexing the strap repeatedly, bending it over and over to the maximum extent possible throughout its length. I 'fixed' the roughness, especially along the edges where it was causing irritation, by rubbing my thumbnail repeatedly along the length. Emery cloth would probably work better and faster but I was concerned about putting too much wear on the stitching. I don't know how long the battery will last but I'm hoping for a couple years. At the price point I paid I'm very happy with the watch so far. Overall it has outperformed similar watches that were much more expensive. If it lasts even a year I'd buy it again.

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Cream Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: This is a great little piece. Second hand adheres closer to the marks on the dial than other Timex models like the Weekender. No loss of seconds yet and I've been wearing it uninterrupted for about two weeks. Face is quite legible and the indiglo is crystal clear. I might have preferred a solid white dial rather than the off-white that this SKU offers but I'm not unhappy with it. It's quite handsome and feels solid. You can definitely hear the ticking when the movement is right next to your ear or if the case is in direct contact with, for example, a wooden desk. Wrapping it in a glass-safe microfiber cloth quiets it quite well though so it isn't quite as maddening as the Weekender movement. The lume on the minute and hour hands is very faint and rarely lasts more than four hours, but is redundant regardless due to the indiglo. Overall a very good watch at this price point.

The only things I would change would be to slightly reduce the size of the watch face and body (it's just a little too large for my small wrist) and to enlarge the date indicator (old eyes), but those really don't detract from the watch.

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Cream Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: I haven't been wearing watches for several years but when I saw this I just had to have it. In a world where there are clocks on our phones, our tablets, our laptops and computers I asked myself why do I need a watch? I pretty much summed it up as this. Wearing a watch is a classy, manly thing and I really did miss wearing a watch everyday. So let's start again with a new watch. Besides, I now don't find myself digging in my pocket for my phone when someone asks me what time is it or when I need to look to see if my if I am running on time to a secret meeting with another covert operative for beers. This Timex has a classic design, with a rugged looking band that appears to be easily replaced down the road. I've only had it less than a week. But it feels like I have been wearing it for much longer than 5 days. I barely notice this on my wrist until I see it peeking out from my shirt sleeve or when I need to check the time. It has a solid feel to it but it doesn't feel heavy or cumbersome. I used to have a bad habit of catching watches on door frames while walking through doorways but I have yet to have this issue with this watch. Perhaps that might change when short sleeve weather comes around? The canvas style band is something new to me and I will have to get used to latching it. With one hole the band is too loose on my wrist and the next hole the band is almost too tight. I do not fault the watch for that small issue. After all, we are all built differently. Will the band stretch in time like my previous watches with leather bands or will it retain its current size? Perhaps in a few weeks or months I will know the answer to that question. As far as looks are concerned it has a classic military look and a rugged feel but by no means does it look like I'm trying to be tacticool. It is classic enough to be worn in the office, casually or in the park or at the beach. You could probably dress this up with a nice leather band for more formal office occasions or situations. But that is just a guess. It was instantly noticed by a few guys at work the first day I wore it into the office. Could it be that they are used to seeing me without a watch or just that it had a nice appeal to it? My wife likes the way it looks on me too. In other words, she didn't dismiss it as some trendy accessory and had nice things to say about the price. What about the Indiglo? Well in the dark it is easily readable. In somewhat dim light the hands seem to reflect enough light they they blend into the background and can be hard to see. But it is easier read without the indiglo in those situations. I really like the yellow seconds hand too. not too bright and just subtle enough to stick out of the black background. Does it keep accurate time? Since I set it after opening the box it appears to keep accurate time. It matches time with my Citizen, Fossil watches as well as my iPhone. If it loses any time I have yet to notice. What about the loud ticking? I don't hear it unless I put the watch up to my ear then it makes an audible tick. I have yet to hear it sitting on the nightstand next to my bed or even while wearing it. I have yet to get it wet, sweaty, dirty or banged up. But give me time, it will happen, I assure you. We will see if it stands up to regular daily use after I give it a thorough going over. I think with the classic styling of this watch it will look just as good with nicks and scratches as it does brand new. I am sure to add pictures and a follow up review down the road. I really like this watch and hope it takes a licking and keeps on ticking.

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Cream Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: Full Disclosure: I bought this watch during Amazonâ€™s Prime Day. The price I paid for it may not be reflective of its current price on Amazon. First off, I done a complete 180 degrees in my watch collection(Budget watch collection that is). Iâ€™ve reverted back to quartz and solar for my current watches. I have only one moderately price automatic in my collection. Back to the watch, it wears well on my 6 3/4â€ wrist. The leather strap is above average for watches in this price point. The watch face in closer to dark gray than full black. The dial has printed numbers and text with a date window in the 3 Oâ€™clock position. However the chapter ring is elevated and slightly sloped towards the dial to give this watch face a sense of depth. The numbers and 5 second hashed are luminous and are easy to read. Likes: Super quiet and reliable solar quartz movement Second hand is aligned properly to every minute marker. Dial is easy to read with some very nice design elements . Leather strap is better than average Dislikes: ( take with a grain of salt considering the value) Crown is pressed in like many Timex quartz watches. Not that you would have to replace the battery anytime soon but water resistance is limited to 50m . Lume is good but not great . At first the 5 second markers and hands are bright. The hands outlast the markers by a wide margin. No Indiglo feature like quartz battery only watches. This is probably due to draw of this feature. Overall, this is a perfect everyday knock around watch. It should give you years of reliable service with great accuracy. A really nice solar option

column2: Timex Men's Expedition Scout 40mm Watch â€“ Black Case Cream Dial with Green Fabric Strap
column14: I really like this watch. When shopping for a simple, inexpensive watch it came down to this Expedition Scout and the Easy Reader. I went with the Expedition because it cost a little less and the Easy Reader looked a little too childish. The first day I wore the Expedition, though, I regretted the decision. The whole reason for an analog watch, in my opinion, is because I need to know with a quick glance what time it is, more or less: it's quarter-of, or five past, etc. A digital may be clearer to read (maybe) but I don't need to know it's 2:06 or 11:43; five past and quarter-of are close enough. Because of the 24-hour time and the hands being white outlined in black on the Expedition Scout, the face is a little busy. I had to look at the watch more than just quickly glance at it. But after living with the Expedition for just one day I am now completely used to it and any trace of regret is erased. I like the look of it, it fits my skinny wrist well, the band has notches in the right place. The thickness from face to back is substantial without looking crazy. I wish I could have gotten a black band but that's not an option with a white face. One ding is that the date is nearly useless. It's reeeaallly small. And it doesn't light up with the Indiglo, which maybe would help readability. I don't care about that feature, but maybe you do. And maybe if your eyes are better you won't have a problem. I read reviews on the Timex site and apparently the crown is a weak link. It's easy to knock off or break. I bought the four dollar Asurion warranty here which will hopefully mitigate that risk. And another thing. The Timex site offers fifteen percent off if you give them your e-mail address. I signed up but the discount didn't show up in my cart at checkout. I called and the rep said it takes a couple days for them to e-mail a coupon code. Seriously? Maybe in 1995 that would be acceptable. Three days later, no code, so I bought it here with same-day shipping. (Now two weeks later and still no code, BTW. Bastards.)

Size is a little on the small end but is extremely comfortable to wear and long sleeves easily cover this watch. The "field" design is sharp and the band is pretty comfortable and breaks in quickly. column14: The buttons are difficult to press. You pretty much have to use your nail to press a button. They are hard to press with the pad of your finger. The adjust button (the top left button) takes an unreasonable amount of force. The adjust button is recessed, whereas the other buttons stick out. In order to record a split you have to press the adjust button which is very difficult to do with the watch on your wrist. Also, the previous split time goes away once you hit the adjust button again, and youâ€™re expected to write down the split time in order to record it. This is unacceptable when running races, where you want to keep track of your mile split times. The light only illuminates the screen for two seconds. It feels like a durable watch, but the buttons make the watch fairly useless.

column2: Casio Men's G-Shock Quartz Watch with Resin Strap, Black, 20 (Model: DW5600E-1V)
column14: I bought this watch in 2014 for use when camping and hiking. I had owned a Timex (Expedition) for many years and it served me well and kept accurate time. Unfortunately, I lost that watch and Amazon didn't have a Timex (Expedition) in stock. So, I read the reviews and then bought this Casio. First and foremost, my Casio does NOT and NEVER did keep accurate time. The watch cost me $41.36 in 2014, which was about $10.00 more than the Timex (Expedition). The buttons on this Casio are almost impossible to depress, whereas the buttons on the Timex are a breeze to operate, especially the large light button on the face of the watch. Twice every year, I regret buying this watch. In the spring when I have to set it forward and in the fall when I have to set it back. It typically gains about 10 minutes over that period of time. I've never owned a quartz movement that gained 20 minutes over the course of a year. If you're looking for ease of use and accuracy, I respectfully suggest that you look elsewhere.

This morning I woke up in a panic when I saw it reported the day as Thursday. For a moment I thought I missed work. Issue 2: if you look at the pictures, there are four silver buttons - two on each side of the watchâ€™s interface. The top left button labeled A in the instruction manual is completely depressed in. To access the options assigned to this button I had to use pen and press down. I believe over time this button will sink deep in the leather contours of the watch. Other than that, watch is a decent watch. $30 at best.

column2: Casio Men's G-Shock Quartz Watch with Resin Strap, Black, 20 (Model: DW5600E-1V)
column14: As others have said, the A-Adjust button on the delivered watch required a pointed object (toothpick, ball point pen, etc.) to depress. No amount of finger-pushing or using a fingernail would make it engage. The countdown timer was one feature I was looking forward to using as a barbecue cooking timer. The beep when the countdown was completed was so extremely faint it was not audible unless the watch was held mashed into my ear. This is the 2nd Casio watch from Amazon that was defective. I previously ordered a Casio G-Shock model, ~$250, from a major retailer that was also delivered defective, with the A-Adjust button missing. Extremely disappointed with this product line.

column14: Worked well for a time. After a few (6-8) months of owning it, the light stopped working and the alarm stopped being reliable (only working about half the time). Everything else about the watch is just fine. Would have been quite satisfied with it if it had not malfunctioned. Update 12/17/15 - Watch is worse now. If I set an alarm, the alarm rings for half a second and resets the clock time to 12:00AM Friday January 1st. The display is weak and hard to see, especially in certain light. My advice is avoid this watch.

Not happy. It's difficult to use, hard to see the numbers, and almost impossible to engage the buttons. One of the complaints about the Timex was that the buttons were too easy to engage. Well, that is definitely not a problem with the Casio. I can hardly press them. I have to use my fingernail, and press really hard to get them to work. I won't ever buy another. This one will last a long time because I don't ever wear it. I bought a cheap Timex Sports, and wear it all the time.

column2: Casio Men's G-Shock Quartz Watch with Resin Strap, Black, 20 (Model: DW5600E-1V)
column14: I have owned several Casio G-Shocks over the last 20+ years and have always gotten good service out of them. They have always lasted over 4-5 years each and I have a solar powered one that is still going strong. I would still be using it but it had too many bells and whistles and I wanted a simpler g-shock that had only a few features like the alarm and a large display. This one seemed to fit the bill perfectly. That's why it also was a great disappointment. The strap broke after the warranty period was over at one year, 2 months. I was lucky to find a generic replacement that fit, so not a big deal. However, after one year, 6 months, the display got glitchy where only the bottom half of the numbers displayed. A local Casio authorized watch repair shop said the battery was probably bad and possibly the lcd. But the cost to replace just the battery would be close to what I paid for the watch itself and there would be no guarantee on the water resistence. To send it back to Casio would be just throwing more good money after bad as I would have to pay for all shipping, insurance etc. Just not worth it for this watch. I understand these are, in fine watch parlance, throw away watches. Use them for several years and when they break down, throw them away and buy another. But at only 1 1/2 years? I expected much better from Amazon and especially Casio.

column2: Casio Men's 'Vintage' Quartz Metal and Resin Casual Watch, Color:Black (Model: F-91WM-9ACF), Black/Gold
column14: Don't get me wrong. Casio makes really good watches and sells them at a very low price. This watch, the F91W-1 is a great example of this....HOWEVER....they compromise drastically with the watch band. I have a very average size wrist but am forced to use the second to last hole in the band. By doing so, the keeper which you tuck the "remainder" of the band into is barely able to hold it. It would not cost much, if even a dollar to lengthen the bands on watches like the F91W-1. The F28-W is another one with short-band-itis. Because of the way the band is somewhat integrated into the design of the watch, changing/upgrading bands is not easy to do. Plus, removing and reinstalling the pins which secure the band to the watch is almost sure to damage the plastic tabs they mount in. Trust me, I've done it. One of Casio's best budget-priced watches, in my opinion, is the W201-1AV. Ample band length, shows day/month & date without pushing a button, PLUS a 10-year battery. Casio, please upgrade the bands on the other aforementioned watches among others.

column14: I prefer the Twist-o-flex style watchband, so my intent from the beginning was to replace the band that came with this watch. column2: Casio Men's 'Vintage' Quartz Metal and Resin Casual Watch, Color:Black (Model: F-91WM-9ACF), Black/Gold
column14: So, I like to wear a watch around the house and when I sleep. I have a decent sized watch collection, but few things I consider to be my home utility watch. I wanted to add to that collection, so that was the mindset I had for this piece. This piece has a lot of history, which is cool, and it serves the primary function of telling time fine. However, there is some utility it lacks, and in all honesty I would tell you to pass on this watch. So hear is what I can say: Intended Use: Around the house utility with need for in the dark functionality. That said it fared ok at this. It is pretty small, but very clear to read. It is a very small thin watch, even on my skinny wrists, but still is able to be read in a lit room or outside easily. I do enjoy that I do not notice it, which makes it easier for doing tasks without snagging it or having it impede mobility. The negative is that this light is the worst I have ever had on a watch. You get the hour and that is about it. This really killed the use for me as I like to be able to check the time quickly at night without the use of my phone. Also, I use my watches for cooking, and without a countdown timer, there goes another aspect of functionality I would like. Remember it has a stopwatch, but no countdown timer. My recommendation would be to spend an extra ten bucks and get the really cool Casio World Time that gives you a better light, timer, stopwatch, and different time zones for travel. It is also a lot bigger and easier to read at night. I greatly prefer that watch. This watch however does do a killer job of telling you the time and date, and if you are looking for something with the least amount of wrist-presence while telling you the time effectively then this is a great watch. If you want much more out of it, there is a lot better for not a lot more money.

column2: Casio Men's 'Vintage' Quartz Metal and Resin Casual Watch, Color:Black (Model: F-91WM-9ACF), Black/Gold
column14: I bought this to replace my AE1200WH after it broke at the lug. Before that one I had an AE1000W, which is the same as the 1200WH (it just looks different). I bought this because I wanted to try a slightly cheaper watch. However, I'd go back to the AE1200WH in a heartbeat. If you have a couple extra bucks, buy an AE watch. I wish I had known that F91-W's had push pins instead of spring pins. I intended on changing the strap for a NATO strap when I unboxed it, but it took a lot of effort to take them out without scratching the plastic. I could've just gotten an AE Casio. They have wide spring-loaded pins, which will make changing straps easier, and give you more strap options. This watch beeps whenever you press buttons, and you can't turn it off (you can in both AE models). The built-in light doesn't really do much, while the AE models light up the whole display. AE models tell you the month. AE models also have world time, a longer stopwatch, and a timer countdown function. You can swim and take a shower with an AE and still keep your warranty. Plus, the AE1200WH looks a lot nicer than the F91-W, and I've gotten a bit of attention when I wear the AE. Anyway, enough comparing this watch to the AE. The F91-W is still a great watch and tells me all I need to know at a moment's glance. Very useful for a kid with only a few bucks in his pocket who doesn't need a million features on his wrist.
column16: Affordable, but would spend more to get a better watch

In some ways it worked, but really the screen is hard to see in all but well-lit spaces and the green â€œlightâ€ function is so dim you literally cannot see the right half of the screen. So essentially the one valuable thing this watch has was rendered nigh-useless in common conditions like dimly lit rooms and the nighttime. Also worth noting: the watch band is very small. column14: The Casio F91W-1 Classic Resin Strap Digital Sport Watch is a popular and affordable timepiece that has been around for decades. Despite its simple design, this watch has a lot to offer. Pros: Affordable: This watch is priced very affordably, making it accessible to a wide range of consumers. Lightweight: The watch is very lightweight and comfortable to wear, which makes it suitable for all-day wear. Durable: The watch is made from high-quality materials and is built to last, which means you can expect to get years of use out of it. Water-resistant: The watch is water-resistant, which makes it suitable for everyday wear, even in wet conditions. Easy to read: The digital display of the watch is clear and easy to read, which makes it easy to tell the time at a glance. Cons: Small screen: The screen of the watch is quite small, which may make it difficult to read for some users. Overall, the Casio F91W-1 Classic Resin Strap Digital Sport Watch is a reliable and affordable option for those in need of a basic timepiece. With its lightweight design, water-resistant construction, and clear digital display, this watch is a great choice for everyday wear.

column2: Casio Men's 'Vintage' Quartz Metal and Resin Casual Watch, Color:Black (Model: F-91WM-9ACF), Black/Gold
column14: My first purchase of this time piece iwas wonderful . This was my second watch as I broke the 1st one. I didn't care for the strap that came with it and bought a velco strap (Amazon.com - Voguestrap TX51012BK Allstrap 16-20mm Black Adjustable-Length Perforated Nylon Sport Strap Watchband) to replace the strap with the buckle. I had an awful time trying to take the stiff posts off the time piece, as it wouldn't slide out and did not have the spring collapsible post that is much easier to remove and install. It was extremely difficult to push or slide the posts out of the holes. As a result I had to bend the post to get it off. After finally getting it off the time piece, I straightened the post and struggled to install my preferred watch band. To add insult to injury, the light did not cover the entire time piece and I could see only the hour numbers and not minute numbers in the dark. I could have returned to have it replaced, but didn't feel like going through the aggravation of contacting Amazon to arrange an exchange and I certainly didn't want to go through the hassle again of transferring the preferred watch band to the replaced time piece.

column2: Casio Men's 'Vintage' Quartz Metal and Resin Casual Watch, Color:Black (Model: F-91WM-9ACF), Black/Gold
column14: The last couple of these I've bought (I've been wearing Casio watches for many years) were the larger, bulkier Sport models, which have larger, easier to read screen, and a few more features -- but much bulkier, and the straps were always oversize for my small wrists. Maybe that's one reason the bands never last long? But my guess is, poor Chinese plastic & quality control. My last two watches still work, and keep perfect time -- but it's a real pain to change the band. So when it broke, I thought, hell with it. For ten bucks... These would likely fit women too, who prefer this style of watch. It is absurd to have to toss a perfectly good watch (w/ a 10-yr battery!) in the drawer, b/c the new band costs as much as a new watch! It is also annoying that each different Casio module has a different time-set sequence. This one is even LESS intuitive than the last. Bah. I just attempted to link instructions on how to turn off the annoying hourly beep -- since the instructions Casio supplies flat don't work. So I guess you're on your own. Hint: boxerwatches[dot]com instructions do work. Black mark to Amazon for blocking my comment!

column14: The watch certainly keeps very good time but that's where it ends. The light is not bright enough to be very useful at all. The alarm is too quiet to hear if there is any significant ambient noise. The biggest problem, however, is the length of the band. While I am not small, I feel that I have a normal sized wrist and this watch is tight even on the last hole. In addition, because the band is so short, on the last hole or two the tail of the band does not remain in the retainer and sticks out, hanging up on the sleeve of my shirt. The band needs to be an inch or so longer. If you have a small wrist, this watch would be fine if you don't care about the light or the alarm.

column2: Casio Men's 'Vintage' Quartz Metal and Resin Casual Watch, Color:Black (Model: F-91WM-9ACF), Black/Gold
column14: Don't get me wrong. Casio makes really good watches and sells them at a very low price. This watch, the F91W-1 is a great example of this....HOWEVER....they compromise drastically with the watch band. I have a very average size wrist but am forced to use the second to last hole in the band. By doing so, the keeper which you tuck the "remainder" of the band into is barely able to hold it. It would not cost much, if even a dollar to lengthen the bands on watches like the F91W-1. The F28-W is another one with short-band-itis. Because of the way the band is somewhat integrated into the design of the watch, changing/upgrading bands is not easy to do. Plus, removing and reinstalling the pins which secure the band to the watch is almost sure to damage the plastic tabs they mount in. Trust me, I've done it. One of Casio's best budget-priced watches, in my opinion, is the W201-1AV. Ample band length, shows day/month & date without pushing a button, PLUS a 10-year battery. Casio, please upgrade the bands on the other aforementioned watches among others.

column14: I prefer the Twist-o-flex style watchband, so my intent from the beginning was to replace the band that came with this watch. However, the lugs that come with the watch are not the springloaded type. I had to cut the band off and then use pliers to pull out the original lugs before adding the new band with conventional spring lugs. My brand new watch has some scratches on it, as a result. Aside from that inconvenience, I am very happy with the watch.

column14: The watch itself is fine. Does what it says and looks good. It is smaller than most watches you see these days but that is okay for me. My problem is that the wristband is equally small - as though this watch was intended for a child or a woman. If you have the wrist of an average and above size man this wristband is barely usable. It is very short. I have to work very carefully to be able to get the band to reach around and fit through the opposing band buckle and I can just get it to fit using the last available hole in the band to hold it closed. This is a lot of effort for what should be a very simple and quick task. The description on the Amazon page for this watch should include this detail - Not suited for larger wrists. Or better yet - supply a larger, longer wristband.

column2: Casio Men's 'Vintage' Quartz Metal and Resin Casual Watch, Color:Black (Model: F-91WM-9ACF), Black/Gold
column14: These Casio watches are the best watches out there for function and waterproofing. I swim and shower and jacuzzi in them regularly and they are tough and wonderful. I have to buy a new one every 12-18 months, and have been buying a new one that often for the past 6 years. All the different colors seemed to last the same. I still have a few of my earlier watches but the straps have broken off. This particular clear version became slightly yellow and discolored after only a few months, probably from Chlorine, and then went dead after only 18 months. I can't find a better watch so I'm buying it again! Definitely only worth $10 with how often they break, but the market for these awesome watches is slim so I'm stuck overpaying.

column2: Casio Men's 'Vintage' Quartz Metal and Resin Casual Watch, Color:Black (Model: F-91WM-9ACF), Black/Gold
column14: So, I like to wear a watch around the house and when I sleep. I have a decent sized watch collection, but few things I consider to be my home utility watch. I wanted to add to that collection, so that was the mindset I had for this piece. This piece has a lot of history, which is cool, and it serves the primary function of telling time fine. However, there is some utility it lacks, and in all honesty I would tell you to pass on this watch. So hear is what I can say: Intended Use: Around the house utility with need for in the dark functionality. That said it fared ok at this. It is pretty small, but very clear to read. It is a very small thin watch, even on my skinny wrists, but still is able to be read in a lit room or outside easily. I do enjoy that I do not notice it, which makes it easier for doing tasks without snagging it or having it impede mobility. The negative is that this light is the worst I have ever had on a watch. You get the hour and that is about it. This really killed the use for me as I like to be able to check the time quickly at night without the use of my phone. Also, I use my watches for cooking, and without a countdown timer, there goes another aspect of functionality I would like. Remember it has a stopwatch, but no countdown timer. My recommendation would be to spend an extra ten bucks and get the really cool Casio World Time that gives you a better light, timer, stopwatch, and different time zones for travel. It is also a lot bigger and easier to read at night. I greatly prefer that watch. This watch however does do a killer job of telling you the time and date, and if you are looking for something with the least amount of wrist-presence while telling you the time effectively then this is a great watch. If you want much more out of it, there is a lot better for not a lot more money.

column2: Casio Men's 'Vintage' Quartz Metal and Resin Casual Watch, Color:Black (Model: F-91WM-9ACF), Black/Gold
column14: I bought this to replace my AE1200WH after it broke at the lug. Before that one I had an AE1000W, which is the same as the 1200WH (it just looks different). I bought this because I wanted to try a slightly cheaper watch. However, I'd go back to the AE1200WH in a heartbeat. If you have a couple extra bucks, buy an AE watch. I wish I had known that F91-W's had push pins instead of spring pins. I intended on changing the strap for a NATO strap when I unboxed it, but it took a lot of effort to take them out without scratching the plastic. I could've just gotten an AE Casio. They have wide spring-loaded pins, which will make changing straps easier, and give you more strap options. This watch beeps whenever you press buttons, and you can't turn it off (you can in both AE models). The built-in light doesn't really do much, while the AE models light up the whole display. AE models tell you the month. AE models also have world time, a longer stopwatch, and a timer countdown function. You can swim and take a shower with an AE and still keep your warranty. Plus, the AE1200WH looks a lot nicer than the F91-W, and I've gotten a bit of attention when I wear the AE. Anyway, enough comparing this watch to the AE. The F91-W is still a great watch and tells me all I need to know at a moment's glance. Very useful for a kid with only a few bucks in his pocket who doesn't need a million features on his wrist.
column16: Affordable, but would spend more to get a better watch

column14: Almost as if the Casio gods were watching over me, I started having issues with this watch after I submitted my initial review a couple weeks ago. The watch seems to die often, with the screen going blank and the watch resetting itself several minutes later (losing the time I had set on it). The bottom-right button almost never registers when I press it, making it borderline impossible to change the settings (time, alarm, stopwatch, 12/24h, etc.). I guess you get what you pay for, and because of that, I'm not really upset by it -- the watch is really cheap after all. Just wish it would've lasted longer because I don't want to go through the effort of buying a new watch once a year.

Cons: Small screen: The screen of the watch is quite small, which may make it difficult to read for some users. Overall, the Casio F91W-1 Classic Resin Strap Digital Sport Watch is a reliable and affordable option for those in need of a basic timepiece. column2: Casio Men's 'Vintage' Quartz Metal and Resin Casual Watch, Color:Black (Model: F-91WM-9ACF), Black/Gold
column14: I loved this watch until the band broke. I paid $14 for it and couldn't justify paying another $8 for a new band. This is a good watch if you don't mind replacing it every couple years when the band breaks, myself I just bought a Eco drive and called it good. So my review is this it's a good cheap watch if you need a good cheap watch and want a watch where if something happens to it you really don't care.

column2: Casio Men's 'Vintage' Quartz Metal and Resin Casual Watch, Color:Black (Model: F-91WM-9ACF), Black/Gold
column14: My first purchase of this time piece iwas wonderful . This was my second watch as I broke the 1st one. I didn't care for the strap that came with it and bought a velco strap (Amazon.com - Voguestrap TX51012BK Allstrap 16-20mm Black Adjustable-Length Perforated Nylon Sport Strap Watchband) to replace the strap with the buckle. I had an awful time trying to take the stiff posts off the time piece, as it wouldn't slide out and did not have the spring collapsible post that is much easier to remove and install. It was extremely difficult to push or slide the posts out of the holes. As a result I had to bend the post to get it off. After finally getting it off the time piece, I straightened the post and struggled to install my preferred watch band. To add insult to injury, the light did not cover the entire time piece and I could see only the hour numbers and not minute numbers in the dark. I could have returned to have it replaced, but didn't feel like going through the aggravation of contacting Amazon to arrange an exchange and I certainly didn't want to go through the hassle again of transferring the preferred watch band to the replaced time piece.
column16: Difficult to remove and install posts to replace the wrist strap

column2: Casio Men's 'Vintage' Quartz Metal and Resin Casual Watch, Color:Black (Model: F-91WM-9ACF), Black/Gold
column14: The last couple of these I've bought (I've been wearing Casio watches for many years) were the larger, bulkier Sport models, which have larger, easier to read screen, and a few more features -- but much bulkier, and the straps were always oversize for my small wrists. Maybe that's one reason the bands never last long? But my guess is, poor Chinese plastic & quality control. My last two watches still work, and keep perfect time -- but it's a real pain to change the band. So when it broke, I thought, hell with it. For ten bucks... These would likely fit women too, who prefer this style of watch. It is absurd to have to toss a perfectly good watch (w/ a 10-yr battery!) in the drawer, b/c the new band costs as much as a new watch! It is also annoying that each different Casio module has a different time-set sequence. This one is even LESS intuitive than the last. Bah. I just attempted to link instructions on how to turn off the annoying hourly beep -- since the instructions Casio supplies flat don't work. So I guess you're on your own. Hint: boxerwatches[dot]com instructions do work. Black mark to Amazon for blocking my comment!
column16: Basic watch, small & light -- but with a pitiful light!

column2: Casio Men's 'Vintage' Quartz Metal and Resin Casual Watch, Color:Black (Model: F-91WM-9ACF), Black/Gold
column14: The watch certainly keeps very good time but that's where it ends. The light is not bright enough to be very useful at all. The alarm is too quiet to hear if there is any significant ambient noise. The biggest problem, however, is the length of the band. While I am not small, I feel that I have a normal sized wrist and this watch is tight even on the last hole. In addition, because the band is so short, on the last hole or two the tail of the band does not remain in the retainer and sticks out, hanging up on the sleeve of my shirt. The band needs to be an inch or so longer. If you have a small wrist, this watch would be fine if you don't care about the light or the alarm.
